title: China renovates anti-malaria center in Maputo
description: In April 2008, the Chinese Government and the Government of Mozambique signed a grant agreement to establish a malaria control center in Maputo. This project involved the construction of laboratories and training rooms, the provision of equipment, and the dispatching of doctors to train staff. The center began operations on October 30, 2009, and it was officially handed over to the authorities on November 25, 2009.   4 malaria experts were dispatched on September 15, 2009 to Angola for 45 days and then to Mozambique for another 45 days to help with malaria control training. These expert visits are captured in Project ID #68603 and Project ID#68605, respectively.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 莫桑比克疟疾防治中心对外 or 我援莫桑比克疟疾防治中心.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China renovates anti-malaria center in Maputo

# Description
In April 2008, the Chinese Government and the Government of Mozambique signed a grant agreement to establish a malaria control center in Maputo. This project involved the construction of laboratories and training rooms, the provision of equipment, and the dispatching of doctors to train staff. The center began operations on October 30, 2009, and it was officially handed over to the authorities on November 25, 2009.   4 malaria experts were dispatched on September 15, 2009 to Angola for 45 days and then to Mozambique for another 45 days to help with malaria control training. These expert visits are captured in Project ID #68603 and Project ID#68605, respectively.
justification: Project focuses on healthcare infrastructure and training without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of laboratories and training rooms, provision of equipment, malaria control training

title: Chinese Government provides grant for a Rural Primary School Construction Project
description: In 2008, the Chinese Government and the Government of Mozambique signed a grant agreement for a Rural Primary School Construction Project. The value of this grant commitment is unknown. The project involved the construction of a rural primary school — with 5 classrooms, 3 offices for teachers, 2 bathrooms, a library, a commissary and pantry, and a guard room — within Massingir District and Gaza Province. China Gansu International Corporation for Economic and Technical Cooperation (CGICOP) was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project was officially completed and handed over to the authorities on August 18, 2010.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 建农村小学项目 or 建莫桑比克加扎省乡村学校工程.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides grant for a Rural Primary School Construction Project

# Description
In 2008, the Chinese Government and the Government of Mozambique signed a grant agreement for a Rural Primary School Construction Project. The value of this grant commitment is unknown. The project involved the construction of a rural primary school — with 5 classrooms, 3 offices for teachers, 2 bathrooms, a library, a commissary and pantry, and a guard room — within Massingir District and Gaza Province. China Gansu International Corporation for Economic and Technical Cooperation (CGICOP) was the contractor responsible for implementation. The project was officially completed and handed over to the authorities on August 18, 2010.
justification: Project is focused on education infrastructure with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of rural primary school with classrooms, offices, and support facilities

title: China Eximbank provides RMB 308.8 million government concessional loan for Palace of Justice Construction Project
description: On April 29, 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of Mozambique signed an RMB 308,800,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Palace of Justice Construction Project. The borrowing terms of the loan included a 22-year maturity, a 7-year grace period, and a 2% interest rate.   The project involved the construction of the Palace of Justice Office Complex, which includes a 12 story building for the Public Prosecutor's Office, Ministry of Justice, Supreme Court of Appeal, National Anti-Corruption Bureau, and Criminal Steering Committee.   China National Complete Equipment Import and Export Corporation (COMPLANT) and the Mozambican CCM Company were the contractors responsible for implementation. A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on August 22, 2008. However, construction did not begin until November 1, 2008. The project was originally expected to be finished within 24 months. However, it was ultimately completed and handed over to the authorities on October 28, 2010. A formal project completion ceremony took place on February 10, 2011.   There are some indications that the China Eximbank loan for the Palace of Justice Construction Project may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. In 2016, several credit rating agencies downgraded the Government of Mozambique to 'selective default' or 'restricted default' status, and the World Bank and the IMF re-classified Mozambique's external debt as 'in distress.' In January 2017, the Government of Mozambique defaulted on a coupon payment for its dollar-denominated Eurobond. Then, in February 2018, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) announced that the Government of Mozambique had accumulated $710 million in arrears to external creditors and had agreed to reschedule some bilateral debt service payments with the Chinese Government. Two months later, in April 2018, Stelia Neta, a National Director at the Ministry of Finance of Mozambique revealed that the Government of Mozambique’s outstanding debt obligations to the Chinese Government amounted to $2.02 billion and the Chinese Government had agreed to extend the grace periods (and first principal repayments) on these outstanding debt obligations without changing their final maturity dates or interest rates (as captured via Project ID#66283).
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Procuratorate Office Building Construction Project. The Portuguese project title is Projeto Palácio De Justiça. The Chinese project title is 建的莫总检察院办公楼项目 or 总检察院大楼项目 or 莫桑比克检察院项目 or 检察院大楼建造项目. 2. In the database of Chinese loan commitments that it released in July 2020, SAIS-CARI records the loan commitment year as 2011. AidData records the loan commitment year as 2008 because the loan agreement was finalized on April 29, 2008.3. The borrowing terms of the loan are drawn from the following source: https://sdgfinance.undp.org/sites/default/files/DFA%20Mozambique.pdf4. One source (https://sdgfinance.undp.org/sites/default/files/DFA%20Mozambique.pdf) suggests that a second (interest-free loan) from MOFCOM was issued in 2011 to support the Palace of Justice Construction Project. This issue warrants further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China Eximbank provides RMB 308.8 million government concessional loan for Palace of Justice Construction Project

# Description
On April 29, 2008, China Eximbank and the Government of Mozambique signed an RMB 308,800,000 government concessional loan (GCL) agreement for the Palace of Justice Construction Project. The borrowing terms of the loan included a 22-year maturity, a 7-year grace period, and a 2% interest rate.   The project involved the construction of the Palace of Justice Office Complex, which includes a 12 story building for the Public Prosecutor's Office, Ministry of Justice, Supreme Court of Appeal, National Anti-Corruption Bureau, and Criminal Steering Committee.   China National Complete Equipment Import and Export Corporation (COMPLANT) and the Mozambican CCM Company were the contractors responsible for implementation. A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on August 22, 2008. However, construction did not begin until November 1, 2008. The project was originally expected to be finished within 24 months. However, it was ultimately completed and handed over to the authorities on October 28, 2010. A formal project completion ceremony took place on February 10, 2011.   There are some indications that the China Eximbank loan for the Palace of Justice Construction Project may have financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. In 2016, several credit rating agencies downgraded the Government of Mozambique to 'selective default' or 'restricted default' status, and the World Bank and the IMF re-classified Mozambique's external debt as 'in distress.' In January 2017, the Government of Mozambique defaulted on a coupon payment for its dollar-denominated Eurobond. Then, in February 2018, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) announced that the Government of Mozambique had accumulated $710 million in arrears to external creditors and had agreed to reschedule some bilateral debt service payments with the Chinese Government. Two months later, in April 2018, Stelia Neta, a National Director at the Ministry of Finance of Mozambique revealed that the Government of Mozambique’s outstanding debt obligations to the Chinese Government amounted to $2.02 billion and the Chinese Government had agreed to extend the grace periods (and first principal repayments) on these outstanding debt obligations without changing their final maturity dates or interest rates (as captured via Project ID#66283).
justification: Project involves construction of government office buildings with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Construction of Palace of Justice Office Complex for government institutions, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Government dispatches 17th medical team to Maputo Central Hospital and the Mavalane General Hospital
description: The Chinese government has been sending batches of medical teams to Mozambique since 1976 from Sichuan Province. The members of the 17th medical team were stationed at Maputo Central Hospital and the Mavalane General Hospital. They completed their term of service between 2008 and 2010.  Other batches include the 13th medical team (#758) sent in 2002, the 14th medical team (#35668) sent in 2004, the 15th medical team (#58090) sent in 2004, the 16th medical team (#57430) sent in 2006, the 18th medical team (#1230) sent in 2010, the 19th medical team in 2012 (#57908), and the 20th medical team in 2014(#60784).
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government dispatches 17th medical team to Maputo Central Hospital and the Mavalane General Hospital

# Description
The Chinese government has been sending batches of medical teams to Mozambique since 1976 from Sichuan Province. The members of the 17th medical team were stationed at Maputo Central Hospital and the Mavalane General Hospital. They completed their term of service between 2008 and 2010.  Other batches include the 13th medical team (#758) sent in 2002, the 14th medical team (#35668) sent in 2004, the 15th medical team (#58090) sent in 2004, the 16th medical team (#57430) sent in 2006, the 18th medical team (#1230) sent in 2010, the 19th medical team in 2012 (#57908), and the 20th medical team in 2014(#60784).
justification: Project focuses on healthcare services without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical teams dispatched to hospitals, healthcare sector focus

title: Chinese government provides training for new leather technology for students from African countries
description: In June 2008, the Chinese government paid for the students from 36 countries, including Kenya, to come to Beijing to learn how to turn cattle hides into finished leather using the latest technology. The countries participating include Tanzania, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Zimbabwe, Zambia, Sierra Leone, Nigeria and more from South America and Asia. China's Ministry of Commerce funded students' flights, accommodation, month-long training course and visits to local tanneries. The training was to last for one month with an estimated completion date in July, 2008.
staff_comments: There is no evidence the training was cancelled or interrupted, so it is assumed to be completed.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
Chinese government provides training for new leather technology for students from African countries

# Description
In June 2008, the Chinese government paid for the students from 36 countries, including Kenya, to come to Beijing to learn how to turn cattle hides into finished leather using the latest technology. The countries participating include Tanzania, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Zimbabwe, Zambia, Sierra Leone, Nigeria and more from South America and Asia. China's Ministry of Commerce funded students' flights, accommodation, month-long training course and visits to local tanneries. The training was to last for one month with an estimated completion date in July, 2008.
justification: Project focuses on skills training and knowledge transfer without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Training program for leather technology, funded by Chinese government, focused on skills development

title: China donates 500,000 USD for cyclone relief to Myanmar in 2008 (linked to project #34212)
description: In May 2008, China donated 500,000 USD in cash to Myanmar for relief efforts in response to Cyclone Nargis. This donation accompanies a 500,000 USD in-kind grant for the same purpose (see project #34212).   The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #54579.

The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #54579.
justification: Humanitarian aid for disaster relief with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Cash donation for cyclone relief, humanitarian purpose

title: China donates goods worth 500,000 USD for cyclone relief to Myanmar in 2008 (linked to project #34211)
description: In May 2008 China sent relief supplies worth 500,000 USD to Myanmar in response to Cyclone Nargis. The goods arrived at Yangon International Airport and were officially handed over on May 7, 2008. The donation included 700 tents, 9,800 blankets, and 13 tons of food. This donation accompanied a 500,000 USD cash donation for the same purpose (see project #34211).   The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #54535.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China donates goods worth 500,000 USD for cyclone relief to Myanmar in 2008 (linked to project #34211)

# Description
In May 2008 China sent relief supplies worth 500,000 USD to Myanmar in response to Cyclone Nargis. The goods arrived at Yangon International Airport and were officially handed over on May 7, 2008. The donation included 700 tents, 9,800 blankets, and 13 tons of food. This donation accompanied a 500,000 USD cash donation for the same purpose (see project #34211).   The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #54535.
justification: Project is humanitarian aid with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Relief supplies for cyclone response, including tents, blankets, and food

title: Chinese Government grants 30 million RMB as aid for Cyclone Nargis
description: On May 8, 2008, China announced an additional in-kind donation of 60 tons of relief supplies worth 30 million RMB for cyclone relief in Myanmar. As part of the donation, on May 9th the 60-ton shipment of medicine, tents, food, water purifiers, and other relief materials arrived at the Yangon International Airport. This emergency aid was in response to the tropical Cyclone Nargis.  The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #54608.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Chinese Government grants 30 million RMB as aid for Cyclone Nargis

# Description
On May 8, 2008, China announced an additional in-kind donation of 60 tons of relief supplies worth 30 million RMB for cyclone relief in Myanmar. As part of the donation, on May 9th the 60-ton shipment of medicine, tents, food, water purifiers, and other relief materials arrived at the Yangon International Airport. This emergency aid was in response to the tropical Cyclone Nargis.  The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Financial Tracking Service lists the project as flow ID #54608.
justification: Project is focused on emergency humanitarian aid without direct environmental or energy transition implications
evidence: Relief supplies including medicine, tents, food, water purifiers for cyclone response

title: Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region donates $250,000 USD for disaster relief in Myanmar after Cyclone Nargis
description: On 2 May 2008, Cycone Nargis hit Myanmar leaving tens of thousands of people dead, missing, or homeless. In response, on 10 May 2008, the Government of Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region (GZAR), region of China, donated $250,000 to the Government of Myanmar for disaster relief efforts.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region donates $250,000 USD for disaster relief in Myanmar after Cyclone Nargis

# Description
On 2 May 2008, Cycone Nargis hit Myanmar leaving tens of thousands of people dead, missing, or homeless. In response, on 10 May 2008, the Government of Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region (GZAR), region of China, donated $250,000 to the Government of Myanmar for disaster relief efforts.
justification: Project is focused on disaster relief and humanitarian aid without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation for disaster relief efforts after Cyclone Nargis, humanitarian focus

title: China donates medical equipment to Myanmar after Cyclone Nagis (linked to #85635)
description: On 2 May 2008, Cycone Nargis hit Myanmar leaving tens of thousands of people dead, missing, or homeless. In response, on May 18, 2008, the Chinese Government sent a 50-person medical team to Yangon, Myanmar to help treat the wounded (see Project #85635). Before returning to China, the medical team donated four medical-use vehicles, medical equipment, and medicines to Myanmar. The value of this donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China donates medical equipment to Myanmar after Cyclone Nagis (linked to #85635)

# Description
On 2 May 2008, Cycone Nargis hit Myanmar leaving tens of thousands of people dead, missing, or homeless. In response, on May 18, 2008, the Chinese Government sent a 50-person medical team to Yangon, Myanmar to help treat the wounded (see Project #85635). Before returning to China, the medical team donated four medical-use vehicles, medical equipment, and medicines to Myanmar. The value of this donation is unknown.
justification: Project involves humanitarian aid and medical assistance without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of medical-use vehicles, medical equipment, and medicines for emergency response
